Is elected Governor of Alaska, defeating former two-term governor Tony Knowles (49% to 41%).

Alaska state legislators vote to hire an investigator to determine if Palin fired former state Public Safety Commissioner Walt Monegan because he would not fire Palin's former brother-in-law, Mike Wooten, a state trooper.
A former state employee files an ethics complaint against Palin accusing her of using her position to get a supporter a government position.
Named as Arizona Senator John McCain's vice presidential running mate.
Announces her 17-year-old daughter, Bristol, is five months pregnant, and the McCain campaign releases a statement that McCain knew about the pregnancy when he selected her as his running mate.
Accepts the Republican Party's nomination for vice president at the Republican National Convention.
State investigator Stephen Branchflower releases a report that Palin abused her power as Alaska's governor and violated state ethics law by trying to get her ex-brother-in-law fired.
Appears on "Saturday Night Live" with Palin lookalike Tina Fey.
Alaska's Personnel Board releases a report concluding that Palin did not violate ethics law in relation to her ex-brother-in-law.
McCain loses the presidential election to Barack Obama.
Launches a political action committee to raise money.
Announces that she will be stepping down as governor of Alaska.
Steps down as governor of Alaska.
Lt. Gov. Sean Parnell becomes governor.
Delivers the keynote address at the first national Tea Party convention.
Discovery Communications announces Sarah Palin will appear in an eight-part documentary series, called "Sarah Palin's Alaska," on the TLC network.
The state of Alaska releases roughly 24,000 pages of emails from Palin's governorship that had been requested in 2008 under the Freedom of Information Act.
Announces she is will not run for president.
Fox News confirms that Palin is no longer an analyst there.
Fox News announces that Palin will rejoin the network as a contributor.

In a Facebook post on Martin Luther King Day, Palin sends a message to President Obama, "Mr. President, in honor of Martin Luther King Jr. and all who commit to ending any racial divide, no more playing the race card."
The subscription-based Sarah Palin Channel launches online.
Politico reports that the Fox News Channel has not renewed Sarah Palin's contract as a paid contributor.
Endorses
Palin's husband, Todd, is seriously injured in a snow machine crash in Alaska and is in intensive care.
He is hospitalized for two weeks.
Files a lawsuit against the New York Times alleging that a recent editorial falsely portrayed her as responsible for inciting the 2011 shooting of Democratic Rep. Gabby Giffords.
A federal judge dismisses Palin's defamation lawsuit against the New York Times, declaring that he sees no evidence of malicious intent.
